FacilityName: TWIN COUNTY SERVICE CO.  HARRISBURG  NH3

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: NH3 BULK TANK, PUMP,VALVES AND HOSES.  NH3 RISER HOSES, VALVES, AND FITTINGS.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
                                                             HARRISBURG, IL -  NH3  SITE

1.   FACILITY ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY POLICY.

      THE MANAGEMENT AND EMPLOYEES OF TWIN COUNTY SERVICE COMPANY ARE COMMITTED TO THE
      PREVENTION OF ANY ACCIDENTIAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA.  IF AN ACCIDENTIAL 
      RELEASE SHOULD OCCUR, THE FACILITY IS PREPARED TO WORK WITH THE LOCAL FIRE DEPT.,
      OR OTHER AUTHORITIES, TO MITIGATE ANY RELEASE AND MINIMIZE THE IMPACT OF THE RELEASE 
      TO PEOPLE AND THE ENVIRONMENT.

2.    THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.

       THE PRIMARY ACTIVITY AT THE FACILITY, WICH IS LOCATED AT 248 CHRISTY ROAD  HARRISBURG, IL,  IS THE STORAGE AND BLENDING OF FERTILIZERS FOR  SALE TO FARMERS.  ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IS RECEIVED, STORED, AND DISTRIBUTED FOR DIRECT APPLICATION AS A CROP PRODUCTION NUTRIENT.
THE STORAGE AND HANDLING SYSTEM CONSISTS OF 1 STORAGE TANK (18,000 GALLONS), LOADING RISERS, ASSOCIATED PLUMBING AND NURSE TANKS.  ACCESS TO THE SITE IS RESTRICTED TO AUTHORIZED  FACILITY EMPLOYEES, AUTHORIZED MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL AND AUTHORIZED CONTRACTORS.
     
        THE MAXIMUM QUANITY OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA THAT CAN BE STORED WOULD BE 158,000 
         POUNDS, THIS INCLUDES ANHYDROUS AMMONIA THAT COULD BE STORED IN NURSE TANKS.

3.    THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO.

       THE WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO WOULD BE THE RELEASE OF THE TOTAL CONTENTS OF A
       STORAGE TANK RELEASED AS A GAS OVER 10 MINUTES.  THE MAXIMUM QUANTITY RELEASED
       WOULD BE 84,000 POUNDS, WHICH REPRESENTS THE VOLUME OF THE LARGEST STORAGE TANK
       AS LIMITEED BY DESIGN STANDARDS.

       THE DISTANCE TO THE ENDPOINT OF .14 MG/L FOR THE WORST-CASE SCENARIO IS 2.0 MILES.

       THE ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO BASED ON THE MOST LIKELY POTENTIAL INCIDENT IS A 
       RELEASE FROM A BREAK IN A TRANSF

ER HOSE. EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN PROCEDURES, WHICH
       INCLUDE THE CLOSING OF TANK VALVES, WAS THE ONLY ACTIVE MITIGATION CONSIDERED  TO 
       LIMIT THE AMOUNT OF THE PRODUCT RELEASED.

       THE DISTANCE TO THE ENDPOINT OF .14 MG/L FOR THE ALTERNATIVE SCENARIO IS .19 MILES. THIS
       RELEASE HAS THE POSSIBILITY OF EXTENDING BEYOUND THE FACILITY BOUNDARY.

4.    THE ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM.

       THIS FACILITY COMPLIES WITH EPA'S ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION RULE AND WITH ALL
       APPLICABLE STATE CODES AND REGULATIONS.  THIS FACILITY HAS IMPLEMENTED THE 
       PROVISIONS OF "SAFETY REQUIREMENTS FOR THE STORAGE AND HANDLING OF ANHYDROUS 
       AMMONIA, K-61.1", PUBLISHED BY THE AMERICAN NATIONAL STANDARDS INSTITUTE, INC. AS
       ADOPTED BY STATE REGULATION AND THE STANDARDS OF THE U.S. OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY
       AND HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "STORAGE AND HANDLING OF
       ANHYDROUS AMMONIA".  COMPLIANCE WITH THESE REGULATIONS AND ON-GOING TRAINING
       OF OUR EMPLOYEES MAKE UP OUR ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM.

5.    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.

       THERE HAVE BEEN NO ACCIDENTIAL RELEASES OF ANHYDROUS AMMONIA IN THE PAST FIVE 
       YEARS THAT;

        - HAVE CAUSED ANY DEATHS, INJURIES, OR SIGNIFICANT PROPERTY DAMAGE AT THE FACILITY;

        - TO OUR KNOWLEDGE, HAVE RESULTED IN OFFSITE DEATHS, INJURIES, EVACUATIONS, SHELTER
           IN PLACE, PROPERTY DAMAGE, OR ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE.

6.    THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.

        THIS FACILITY HAS, A WRITTEN EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN, IN ACCORDANCE WITH OSHA
        STANDARD, 29 CFR 1910.38;
    
        PROVIDED STATE AND LOCAL AUTHORITIES THE EMERGENCY PLANNING AND COMMUNITY
        RIGHT-TO-KNOW INFORMATION AS REQUIRED UNDER SARA TITLE III (EPCRA);

        IN THE EVENT OF AN EMERGENCY INVOLVING ANHYDROUS AMMONIA, IT IS OUR POLICY TO 
        NOTIFY THE HARRISBURG POLICE DEPT AND THE SALINE COUNTY LEPC.

7.    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY.

SAFETY IMPROVEMENT IS AN ON-GOING PROCESS AT THE FACILITY.  PERIODIC EVALUATIONS ARE
       PERFORMED TO ASSESS THE MAINTENANCE OF SAFE CONDITIONS.  THERE ARE NO SPECIFIC 
       SAFETY RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPLEMENTATION AT THIS TIME.
